Tom Hanks.passage: Tom Hanks is an American actor, producer, and director. Hanks is known for his roles in Saving Private Ryan, Forrest Gump, Cast Away, The Da Vinci Code, and The Green Mile. He has won numerous awards for his work, including two Academy Awards, a Golden Globe, and a Screen Actors Guild Award. Hanks was born in Concord, California, in 1956. He grew up in a family of actors and musicians, and began his acting career in high school. After attending college for a year, Hanks dropped out to pursue acting full-time. He landed his first major role in the television series Bosom Buddies in 1980. Hanks' breakthrough role came in 1988 with the film Big, in which he played a 12-year-old boy trapped in the body of a 30-year-old man. The film was a critical and commercial success, and Hanks became a household name. He went on to star in a string of successful films throughout the 1990s, including A League of Their Own, Sleepless in Seattle, and Philadelphia. In addition to his work as an actor, Hanks has also produced and directed several films. He made his directorial debut with the 1996 film That Thing You Do!, which he also wrote and starred in. Hanks has also produced films such as Saving Private Ryan and The Post. Hanks is known for his versatility as an actor, and his ability to bring depth and humanity to his roles. He has been praised for his ability to portray a wide range of characters, from comedic to dramatic.

Julia Roberts.passage: Julia Fiona Roberts (born October 28, 1967) is an American actress and producer. She became a Hollywood star after headlining the romantic comedy Pretty Woman (1990), which grossed $464 million worldwide. She has won three Golden Globe Awards, and has been nominated for four Academy Awards for her film performances, winning the Academy Award for Best Actress for her performance in Erin Brockovich (2000). She has been named one of People magazine's "50 Most Beautiful People in the World" eleven times, tied with Halle Berry for the record. Roberts was born in Smyrna, Georgia, to actors Walter and Betty Lou Roberts. She was raised in Atlanta, Georgia, and attended Fitzhugh Lee Elementary School, Griffin Elementary School, and the Georgia Actors Youth Theatre. After graduating from Smyrna High School, she attended Georgia State University but dropped out after one year to pursue a career in acting. Roberts's first film role came in the film Blood Red (1989), which was not released until 1991. She followed this with a supporting role in the comedy film Mystic Pizza (1988), which was followed by a role in the independent film Satisfaction (1988). Brad Pitt.passage: Brad Pitt (born William Bradley Pitt; December 18, 1963) is an American actor and producer. He has received a Golden Globe Award, a Screen Actors Guild Award, and three Academy Award nominations in acting categories, and received two further Academy Award nominations, winning one, for productions of his film production company Plan B Entertainment. Pitt first gained recognition as a cowboy hitchhiker in the road movie Thelma & Louise (1991). His first leading roles were in the drama film The Dark Side of the Sun (1988) and the thriller film Cutting Class (1989). He made his mark in Hollywood with his role as the charming and charismatic cowboy, Tyler Durden, in the cult hit Fight Club (1999). He received critical acclaim for his performances in the crime film Seven (1995) and the science fiction film 12 Monkeys (1995). He gave a breakthrough performance as the stoner Jimmy Darmody in the HBO series Boardwalk Empire (2010–2014), and received a Golden Globe Award for his supporting role in the biographical crime film The Departed (2006). Pitt has been married three times, to actresses Jennifer Aniston and Angelina Jolie, and model and actress Charlize Theron. He has six children, three of whom were adopted internationally with Jolie. In addition to his acting career, Pitt is a philanthropist and activist, and has donated millions of dollars to charitable organizations and causes.

She has received an Academy Award, two Screen Actors Guild Awards, and three Golden Globe Awards, and has been cited as one of Hollywood's highest-paid actresses. Jolie made her screen debut as a child alongside her father, Jon Voight, in the 1982 film Lookin' to Get Out. She starred in the critically acclaimed biographical cable films George Wallace (1997) and Gia (1998), and won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her performance in the drama Girl, Interrupted (1999). Jolie's starring role as the video game heroine Lara Croft in Lara Croft: Tomb Raider (2001) established her as a leading Hollywood actress. She continued her successful action-star career with Mr. & Mrs. Smith (2005), Wanted (2008), and Salt (2010), and received critical acclaim for her performances in the dramas A Mighty Heart (2007) and Changeling (2008). The awards were first presented in 1929 at a private dinner party attended by around 270 people. The ceremony was held to honor the actors, actresses, and directors of the silent film era. Sophie's Choice.passage: Sophie's Choice is a 1979 American drama film directed by Alan J. Pakula, who adapted the screenplay from the novel of the same name by William Styron. The film stars Meryl Streep, Kevin Kline, and Peter MacNicol. The story is set in Brooklyn in 1947 and focuses on Sophie (Streep), a Polish immigrant who shares a crowded apartment with her lover, Nathan (Kline), and his friend, Stingo (MacNicol). Sophie is haunted by her past, particularly her experiences in Nazi concentration camps, and her love for Nathan is complicated by her tragic history. The film explores themes of love, loss, and survival, and has been praised for its performances, particularly Streep's, which earned her an Academy Award for Best Actress.

Africa.passage: 1. Africa is the world's second-largest and second-most-populous continent. 2. At about 30.3 million km² (11.7 million sq mi) including adjacent islands, it covers six percent of the Earth's total surface area and 20.4 percent of the total land area. 3. With 1.2 billion people as of 2016, it accounts for about 16% of the world's human population. 4. The continent is surrounded by the Mediterranean Sea to the north, both the Suez Canal and the Red Sea along the Sinai Peninsula to the northeast, the Indian Ocean to the southeast, and the Atlantic Ocean to the west. 5. The continent includes Madagascar and various archipelagoes. 6. Africa, particularly central Eastern Africa, is the origin of humans and the Hominidae family, as well as the home of the oldest civilizations. 7. Africa has been inhabited by humans for at least 300,000 years, and the continent was first inhabited by Homo erectus. 8. The continent is home to numerous ethnic groups, each with their own unique culture, history and traditions. 9. Africa has a wide range of climate zones, from the deserts of the north to the tropical forests in the south, and the savannas in between. 10. The continent is home to a diverse array of flora and fauna, including the largest animals such as elephants, giraffes, and rhinoceroses. 11. Africa has been the site of many important civilizations throughout history, including the Ancient Egyptians, Carthaginians, and Romans. 12.

Titanic.passage: The Titanic was a British passenger liner that sank in the North Atlantic Ocean on April 15, 1912, after colliding with an iceberg during its maiden voyage from Southampton to New York City. The sinking of the Titanic resulted in the loss of 1,517 lives, making it one of the deadliest commercial peacetime maritime disasters in modern history. The Titanic was the largest ship afloat at the time it entered service and was one of three Olympic-class ocean liners operated by the White Star Line. It was built by the Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast, Northern Ireland. The Titanic was under the command of Captain Edward Smith, who also went down with the ship. The sinking of the Titanic caused widespread shock and outrage, leading to the establishment of the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS) in 1914. The Titanic has since become one of the most famous ships in history, and its sinking has been the subject of numerous books, films, and other forms of media.

Lion.passage: Lions are large carnivorous cats with a short, bushy tail. They are social animals and live in groups called prides. Lions are native to Africa and some parts of Asia, and are the second largest big cat species after tigers. They are known for their distinctive mane, which is made up of long hairs on the neck, head, and shoulders of male lions. Female lions, called lionesses, are smaller and less muscular than males. Lions are apex predators and are capable of taking down large prey such as zebras, wildebeests, and buffalo. They are also known to scavenge on carrion. Lions are listed as vulnerable on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species, with populations declining due to habitat loss, human-wildlife conflict, and poaching. Conservation efforts are underway to protect lion populations and their habitats.

Emmy Awards.passage: The Primetime Emmy Awards, commonly called the Emmys, are presented annually by the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences (ATAS) to recognize excellence in American primetime television programming. The first Emmy Awards ceremony took place in 1949, and the ceremony has been held annually ever since, except for a hiatus in 1951. The Emmy Awards are considered the television equivalent to the Academy Awards (Oscars) for film. The awards are presented in various categories, such as drama series, comedy series, limited series, television movie, variety series, reality competition, and more. The Primetime Emmy Awards are one of the most prestigious awards in the television industry, and winning an Emmy is considered a significant achievement for actors, actresses, directors, and other professionals in the television industry. Moulin Rouge.passage: Moulin Rouge is a cabaret in Paris, France. The original house, which was built in 1889, was located at 82 Boulevard de Clichy in the Montmartre district of Paris. It was founded by Charles Zidler and Joseph Oller, who also owned the nearby Théâtre des Folies Bergère. The cabaret was closely associated with the Romantic movement of the late 19th century, and it quickly became a popular destination for artists and writers, including Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, Pablo Picasso, and Jean Cocteau. The Moulin Rouge is also known for its famous "French Cancan" dance, which was first performed there in 1893. The cabaret was closed during World War I and reopened in 1921. It has since become a tourist attraction and a symbol of Parisian nightlife.

Jimmy Darmody.passage: Jimmy Darmody was a fictional character in the HBO television series Boardwalk Empire, portrayed by actor Michael Pitt. He was a protégé of the show's main character, Enoch "Nucky" Thompson, and a central figure in the series' first season. Darmody was born in 1899 in New York City to an Irish-American family. He served in World War I and returned to the United States with a Purple Heart. After the war, he became involved in organized crime, working for Nucky Thompson as a bootlegger and enforcer. Darmody was a complex character, torn between his loyalty to Nucky and his desire for independence. He was also haunted by his experiences in the war, which led him to have a violent temper and a tendency to act impulsively. Fight Club.passage: Fight Club is a 1996 novel by Chuck Palahniuk. It follows the experiences of an unnamed protagonist struggling with insomnia and his relationship with Tyler Durden, his projected alter ego. The narrator finds solace in attending underground fights and meets Marla Singer, a woman with similar interests. The novel explores themes of masculinity, consumerism, and anti-consumerism, as well as the concept of the unreliable narrator. The novel was adapted into a 1999 film of the same name directed by David Fincher and starring Brad Pitt and Edward Norton. The film was a commercial success and received critical acclaim for its direction, screenplay, and performances. It has since become a cult classic and is considered a landmark film in the fight genre. Fight Club has been the subject of controversy and debate since its release. Some critics have praised the novel for its commentary on modern society and the male psyche, while others have criticized it for promoting violence and misogyny. The novel has also been banned in some schools and libraries for its graphic content and themes. Despite the controversy, Fight Club has had a significant impact on popular culture. Its themes and imagery have been referenced in various forms of media, including music, art, and literature. The novel has also inspired a subculture of fight clubs and anti-consumerist movements.

Changeling.passage: Changeling is a creature in folklore and mythology that is said to replace a human child with a fairy, troll, or other supernatural entity. The term derives from the Old English word ceolcing, which means "exchanging" or "substituting". In some stories, the changeling is said to be the offspring of the supernatural entity, while in others it is said to be a stolen human child. The concept of the changeling has been found in many cultures around the world, including those of Europe, Asia, and Africa. In some cases, the changeling is said to be able to assume the shape of animals or inanimate objects. In other cases, the changeling is said to be unable to assume any form other than that of a human child. The concept of the changeling has been used in literature and film, including the 2007 film "The Changeling" and the 2011 film "The Secret World of Arrietty".
